id_plant_info.Common_Name: Chinese lantern, Ground cherry, Jerusalem cherry, strawberry tomato
id_plant_info.Description: Perennial herbs, often much branched and spreading at the top; leaves alternate, simple, smooth margined or irregularly toothed; flowers axillary, nodding, 5-parted, bell- or funnel-shaped, yellowish; fruit a globose yellow, red, purple, or blue-black berry surrounded by a papery sac.
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Headache, stomach pain, lowered temperature, dilated pupils, vomiting, diarrhea, circulatory and respiratory depression, loss of sensation; may be fatal.
id_plant_info.Severity: HIGHLY TOXIC, MAY BE FATAL IF EATEN!

id_plant_info.Symptoms: Irritation, redness, and blistering following contact.
id_plant_info.Severity: SKIN IRRITATION SEVERE!

id_plant_info.Description: Floating aquatic; leaves spreading in a rosette on water surface, spongy, rounded, the main veins conspicuously indented above
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Intense burning and swelling of lips, tongue, and throat; nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea may also occur
id_plant_info.Toxic_Principle: Calcium oxalate crystals plus unknown toxins
id_plant_info.Severity: TOXIC ONLY IF LARGE QUANTITIES EATEN.

id_plant_info.Description: Erect annual with milky juice; leaves alternate, simple, clasping, toothed; flowers terminal, with 5-more showy petals (white, pink, red, or purple); fruit a capsule with an expanded disc at the top and over small holes through which the minute seeds are dispersed.
id_plant_info.Poison_Part: Dried milky sap from all parts, but mainly fruits
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Stupor, coma, shallow and slow breathing, respiratory and circulatory depression
id_plant_info.Severity: HIGHLY TOXIC, MAY BE FATAL IF EATEN!

id_plant_info.Description: Evergreen shrub or tree; leaves alternate, simple, narrowly strap-like, dark green with lighter midrib; pollen cones yellowish and elongated; seed light blue, fleshy, with red, enlarged stalk; excellent for Coastal NC; not very hardy in Piedmont
id_plant_info.Poison_Part: Fleshy seeds (resemble fruits) eaten by children.
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea.
id_plant_info.Severity: CAUSES ONLY LOW TOXICITY IF EATEN.

id_plant_info.Description: Perennial herb; stem unbranched, with 1-2 large, rounded, umbrella-like, deeply 5-9-lobed leaves; flower solitary, nodding, in axil between 2 leaves, 6-9 parted, white; fruit apple-like, yellow when ripe
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Salivation, vomiting, diarrhea, excitement, headache, fever, coma
id_plant_info.Severity: HIGHLY TOXIC, MAY BE FATAL IF EATEN!

id_plant_info.Description: Evergreen shrub or tree; leaves alternate, simple, narrowly strap-like, dark green with lighter midrib; pollen cones yellowish and elongated; seed light blue, fleshy, with red, enlarged stalk; excellent for Coastal NC; not very hardy in Piedmont

id_plant_info.Description: Deciduous tree; leaves alternate, simple, toothed on the margin, with 2 small glands at base of blade; flowers usually solitary, 5-parted, white or pinkish; fruit fleshy with a large pit (stone), yellow or reddish
id_plant_info.Poison_Part: Wilted leaves, twigs (stems), seeds; laetrile from the seeds is a dangerous, controversial treatment for cancer
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Gasping, weakness, excitement, pupil dilation, spasms, convulsions, coma, respiratory failure
id_plant_info.Severity: HIGHLY TOXIC, MAY BE FATAL IF EATEN!

id_plant_info.Description: Deciduous tree; leaves alternate, simple, toothed on the margin, with 2 small glands at base of blade; flowers 1-few in a rounded cluster, 5-parted, white; fruit fleshy, yellow or red, with a large pit (stone)
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Gasping, weakness, excitement, pupil dilation, spasms, convulsions, coma, respiratory failure
id_plant_info.Severity: HIGHLY TOXIC, MAY BE FATAL IF EATEN!

id_plant_info.Description: Deciduous tree; leaves alternate, simple, long-pointed, toothed on the margin, with 2 small glands at base of blade; flowers 2-5 in a rounded cluster, each 5-parted, white; fruit fleshy, red, with a large pit (stone)
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Gasping, weakness, excitement, pupil dilation, spasms, convulsions, coma, respiratory failure
id_plant_info.Severity: HIGHLY TOXIC, MAY BE FATAL IF EATEN!

id_plant_info.Description: Deciduous tree; leaves alternate, simple, long-pointed, toothed on the margin, with 2 small glands at base of blade; flowers 1-2, 5-parted, white; fruit fleshy, dark maroon with a large, rough pit (stone)
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Gasping, weakness, excitement, pupil dilation, spasms, convulsions, coma, respiratory failure

id_plant_info.Description: Deciduous tree; leaves alternate, simple, toothed on the margin, with 2 small glands at base of blade and hairy along midrib below; flowers in an elongated cluster, 5-parted, white; fruit fleshy, black with a large pit (stone)
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Gasping, weakness, excitement, pupil dilation, spasms, convulsions, coma, respiratory failure
id_plant_info.Severity: HIGHLY TOXIC, MAY BE FATAL IF EATEN!

id_plant_info.Description: Evergreen or deciduous trees; leaves alternate and simple, variously shaped in different species; pollen flowers in drooping, elongated clusters; fruit an acorn.

id_plant_info.Symptoms: Stomach pain, constipation and later bloody diarrhea, excessive thirst and urination

id_plant_info.Posion_Delivery_Mode: Dermatitis; ingestion of large quantities of raw pineapple and/or sap from leaves

id_plant_info.Toxic_Principle: Bromelin, ethyl acrylate, and calcium oxalate crystals
id_plant_info.Severity: CAUSES SEVERE PAIN IN THE MOUTH IF EATEN! SKIN IRRITATION MINOR OR LASTING ONLY FOR A FEW MINUTES.

id_plant_info.Symptoms: Inflammation and blistering upon contact with fresh sap; irritation of mouth, vomiting and diarrhea following ingestion
id_plant_info.Severity: TOXIC ONLY IF LARGE QUANTITIES EATEN. CAUSES SEVERE PAIN IN THE MOUTH IF EATEN!

id_plant_info.Description: Caladiums are tropical plants with heart-shaped simple alternate leaves ranging in size from 6 to 12 inches. The numerous cultivars offer foliage colors in red, salmon, rose, white, or green with many variegated combinations. Their flower is a spadix surrounded by a yellow-green spathe.  Caladiums prefer a rich soil and shade. Grown mostly for their interesting foliage display, caladiums perform well in garden borders and containers. Fertilize them once a month with 8-8-8 (2 lbs/100 ft2 ). Caladiums do not overwinter in N.C. Therefore, their tubers must be dug in the fall and stored dry at 70 to 75 Â°F. The tubers are replanted in the spring after the last chance of frost. One additional note: most cultivars are adapted to full shade, but many selections tolerate partial sun or early morning sunlight. Full sun generally reduces the intensity of the foliage color of most cultivars.

id_plant_info.Description: Annual or perennial, herbaceous vines with winged stem; leaves alternate, pinnately divided, each with 2 or more leaflets and a terminal tendril; flowers pea-like in elongated clusters, pink; fruit a flattened pod
id_plant_info.Symptoms: "Lathyrism": paralysis, slow and weak pulse, shallow breathing, convulsions
id_plant_info.Severity: TOXIC ONLY IF LARGE QUANTITIES EATEN.

id_plant_info.Common_Name: Blue cardinal flower, Cardinal flower, Indian tobacco, Lobelia
id_plant_info.Description: Erect, annual or perennial herbs; leaves alternate, simple; flowers white, scarlet, or blue, 5-parted, tubular and irregular-shaped with 2 lips; fruit a capsule.
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, salivation, exhaustion and weakness, dilation of pupils, convulsions, and coma
id_plant_info.Toxic_Principle: Alkaloids lobelamine, lobeline, and others, plus a volatile oil
id_plant_info.Severity: TOXIC ONLY IF LARGE QUANTITIES EATEN

id_plant_info.Description: Annual, biennial, or perennial herbs; leaves alternate, simple or palmately divided; flowers showy in terminal, elongated clusters, pea-like, blue to purple, pinkish or white; fruit an elongated, flattened pod.
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Respiratory depression and slow heartbeat, sleepiness, convulsions
id_plant_info.Toxic_Principle: Alkaloids such as lupinine, anagyrine, sparteine, and hydroxylupanine
id_plant_info.Severity: TOXIC ONLY IF LARGE QUANTITIES EATEN

id_plant_info.Common_Name: Matrimony vine, box thorn, false jessamine, wolfberry
id_plant_info.Description: Deciduous or evergreen shrubs with spiny stems; leaves alternate, simple, smooth margined; flowers small, 5-parted, funnel-shaped or bell-shaped, white, lilac, purple; fruit a berry, red to purple or yellow
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Headache, abdominal pain, dilated pupils, vomiting, diarrhea, circulatory and respiratory depression, loss of sensation
id_plant_info.Severity: TOXIC ONLY IF LARGE QUANTITIES EATEN

id_plant_info.Description: Bulbous herbs with basal, strap-shaped leaves; flowering stem stout and hollow bearing 2-many stalked flowers at the top, each horizontal or drooping, funnel-shaped, 6-parted, of various colors.
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, salivation, possibly diarrhea
id_plant_info.Severity: TOXIC ONLY IF LARGE QUANTITIES EATEN.

id_plant_info.Description: A bushy herb or shrub with elongated tubers; leaves alternate, simple, deeply lobed; flowers inconspicuous; fruit a 6-angled globose capsule
id_plant_info.Poison_Part: Raw roots or peelings of the tubers (thickened roots)
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Weak and irregular breathing, weakness, excitement, depression, staggering, pupil dilation, spasms, convulsions, coma of short duration
id_plant_info.Severity: HIGHLY TOXIC, MAY BE FATAL IF EATEN!

id_plant_info.Description: Deciduous tree; leaves alternate, 2-pinnately divided with toothed, pointed leaflets; flowers small but numerous in large terminal clusters, lilac-colored; fruit a yellowish, wrinkled drupe persisting through the winter
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Stomach irritation, vomiting, bloody diarrhea, paralysis, irregular breathing, and respiratory distress
id_plant_info.Toxic_Principle: Tetranortriterpene neurotoxins; also possibly a saponin
id_plant_info.Severity: TOXIC ONLY IF LARGE QUANTITIES EATEN.

id_plant_info.Description: Erect, much branched herb; leaves opposite, simple; flowers opening late in the afternoon or in very cloudy weather, white to red, yellow or striped, tubular and trumpet-like, 5-lobed; fruit leathery, 5-ribbed
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Stomach pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea; handling of the roots may cause dermatitis
id_plant_info.Severity: CAUSES ONLY LOW TOXICITY IF EATEN. SKIN IRRITATION MINOR OR LASTING ONLY FOR A FEW MINUTES.

id_plant_info.Description: Annual, climbing vine; leaves alternate, foul-smelling, deeply palmately lobed; flowers yellow, tubular; fruit a berry, yellow-orange, warty, with red pulp around seeds
id_plant_info.Poison_Part: Outer fruit coat, seeds, ripe fruit
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Headache, salivation, facial redness, pupil dilation, stomach pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, muscular weakness
id_plant_info.Severity: TOXIC ONLY IF LARGE QUANTITIES EATEN.

id_plant_info.Description: Woody vine; leaves alternate, simple, large, leathery, conspicuously lobed and with elongated holes throughout the blade; flowers small on a spadix and surrounded by a greenish or whitish spathe; fruit fleshy and pineapple-like
id_plant_info.Poison_Part: Intense burning of mouth, tongue, and throat; nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea may also occur; contact with cell sap may cause skin irritation
id_plant_info.Symptoms: EDIBLE PARTS: Ripe fruit, but some people are allergic
id_plant_info.Toxic_Principle: Needle-like calcium oxalate crystals; possibly other unidentified toxins
id_plant_info.Severity: TOXIC ONLY IF LARGE QUANTITIES EATEN. CAUSES SEVERE PAIN IN THE MOUTH IF EATEN! SKIN IRRITATION MINOR OR LASTING ONLY FOR A FEW MINUTES.

id_plant_info.Description: Deciduous trees with alternate, simple, toothed leaves, either unlobed, mitten-shaped, or 3-lobed, usually smooth above and hairless below; flowers small in a tight cluster; fruit white, pink, or purplish, clustered like a blackberry
id_plant_info.Poison_Part: Unripe fruit and milky sap from all parts
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Hallucinations and stomach upset
id_plant_info.Severity: CAUSES ONLY LOW TOXICITY IF EATEN.

id_plant_info.Common_Name: Rabbit ears cactus, prickly pear cactus
id_plant_info.Description: Succulent, flattened stems or shrublike with cylindric stems; leaves lacking or modified into large spines; sharp-pointed glochids in clusters at base of spines; flowers variously colored, with many petals; fruit fleshy or dry.
id_plant_info.Poison_Part: Glochids (minute bristle-like, barbed hairs in clusters) on the stems (green, thickened stems resemble leaves).
id_plant_info.Posion_Delivery_Mode: Ingestion; splinter-like small infection due to glochids lodged in the skin, eye irritation.
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Painful skin and eye irritation following contact; internal effects in diabetics from ingestion.
id_plant_info.Toxic_Principle: Unknown; possibly mechanical effect of glochids.
id_plant_info.Severity: CAUSES ONLY LOW TOXICITY IF EATEN. SKIN IRRITATION SEVERE!

id_plant_info.Symptoms: Caution: large quantities may cause trembling, cramps, and staggering as in grazing animals.

id_plant_info.Description: Woody, evergreen or deciduous shrubs; leaves alternate, simple, smooth- or toothed-margined; flowers in a terminal cluster, tubular, 5-parted, white to deep pink or yellow; fruit an elongated capsule.
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Salivation, watering of eyes and nose, abdominal pain, loss of energy, depression, nausea and vomiting, diarrhea, weakness, difficult breathing, progressive paralysis of arms and legs, coma.
id_plant_info.Severity: HIGHLY TOXIC, MAY BE FATAL IF EATEN!

id_plant_info.Description: Shrublike, annual herb with red-purplish stems; leaves large, alternate, simple, round in outline but deeply and palmately 6-11 lobed; flowers small and whitish; fruit a large, red, prickly capsule with slightly flattened seeds which are mottled brown-gray-white
id_plant_info.Posion_Delivery_Mode: Ingestion and allergic reaction after skin contact with seeds
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Immediate or delayed nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, bloody diarrhea, depression, trembling, sweating, convulsions, coma; may be fatal; severe allergic reaction in certain individuals following skin contact with broken seeds
id_plant_info.Toxic_Principle: Ricin, a phytotoxalbumin, plus ricinine, an alkaloid
id_plant_info.Severity: HIGHLY TOXIC, MAY BE FATAL IF EATEN! SKIN IRRITATION SEVERE!

id_plant_info.Description: Large, deciduous tree, with twin spines at the base of the leaf at least in juvenile growth; leaves alternate, pinnately divided with 7-25 leaflets, each elliptical with a smooth margin; flowers white, fragrant, pea-like, in an elongated, drooping cluster; fruit a flattened pod
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Depression, weakness, dilated pupils, vomiting, bloody diarrhea, weak pulse, coldness of arms and legs, paleness, and shock
id_plant_info.Toxic_Principle: Robin, a phytotoxin; robitin, a glycoside; robinine, an alkaloid
id_plant_info.Severity: TOXIC ONLY IF LARGE QUANTITIES EATEN.

id_plant_info.Common_Name: Chinese scholar tree, Japanese pagoda, Japanese pagoda tree
id_plant_info.Description: Deciduolus tree; leaves alternate, pinnately divided into 3-8 pairs of leaflets; flowers pea-like in terminal clusters, creamy white and fragrant; fruit a yellow or yellow-brown pod
id_plant_info.Symptoms: No cases known. Possibly vomiting, diarrhea, excitement, delirium, and coma
id_plant_info.Toxic_Principle: Alkaloids? Suspected due to close relationship to Mescal bean
id_plant_info.Severity: CAUSES ONLY LOW TOXICITY IF EATEN.

id_plant_info.Description: Perennial herb; leaves large and heart-shaped; flowers small in a dark spadix surrounded by a purple-brown spathe, foul-smelling.
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Burning and swelling of lips, tongue, and throat; nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea may also occur
id_plant_info.Toxic_Principle: Calcium oxalate crystals and possibly others
id_plant_info.Severity: TOXIC ONLY IF LARGE QUANTITIES EATEN. CAUSES SEVERE PAIN IN THE MOUTH IF EATEN!

id_plant_info.Description: Evergreen shrub or tree; leaves alternate, pinnately divided with 7-9 leaflets, notched, silky below; flowers pea-like, violet-blue, fragrant; fruit a woody pod with bright red seeds.
id_plant_info.Poison_Part: Seeds, often used in making necklaces
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Vomiting, diarrhea, excitement, delirium, and coma
id_plant_info.Severity: CAUSES ONLY LOW TOXICITY IF EATEN.

id_plant_info.Description: Annual herbs, gland-dotted and aromatic; leaves opposite or alternate above, pinnately lobed and appearing divided, the lobes narrow and toothed; flowers in slender heads, yellow and orange or with red.
id_plant_info.Poison_Part: All parts, mainly roots and flowers
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Skin redness, burning pain, and blisters when broken skin is in contact with cell sap plus sunlight; nose and eye irritation from aroma of flowers
id_plant_info.Severity: Skin irritation is minor, or typically only lasting a few minutes

id_plant_info.Description: Perennial herb; leaves basal, elongated, pointed at both ends, dark green with conspicuously indented veins; flowers small on a spadix surrounded by a white or greenish, flat or concave spathe
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Burning of lips, tongue, and throat
id_plant_info.Severity: TOXIC ONLY IF LARGE QUANTITIES EATEN. CAUSES SEVERE PAIN IN THE MOUTH IF EATEN!

id_plant_info.Description: Evergreen shrub; leaves alternate, simple, linear; seed axillary, with red, fleshy aril nearly surrounding the green seed
id_plant_info.Poison_Part: Bark, leaves, seed pit (red, fleshy surrounding part, called the aril, is OK to eat)
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Nervousness, trembling, slow pulse, pupil dilation, difficult breathing, abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, weakness, convulsions; may be fatal
id_plant_info.Severity: HIGHLY TOXIC, may be fatal if eaten!

id_plant_info.Common_Name: African marigold, American marigold, Aztec marigold
id_plant_info.Description: Annual herbs, gland-dotted and aromatic; leaves opposite or alternate above, pinnately lobed and appearing divided, the lobes narrow and toothed; flowers in slender heads, yellow and orange or with red
id_plant_info.Poison_Part: All parts, mainly roots and flowers
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Skin redness, burning pain, and blisters when broken skin is in contact with cell sap plus sunlight; nose and eye irritation from aroma of flowers
id_plant_info.Severity: Skin irritation is minor, or typically only lasting a few minutes

id_plant_info.Description: Perennial herb, aromatic; leaves alternate, pinnately lobed and appearing divided, with narrow, toothed segments; flowers in tight heads, yellow.  Can be weedy in disturbed areas.
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Rapid, weak pulse, stomach pain, convulsions
id_plant_info.Severity: Toxic only if large quantities eaten

id_plant_info.Description: Bulbous perennial herbs; leaves alternate, simple, narrowly straplike; flowers single, erect, 6-parted, cup-shaped, of various colors.
id_plant_info.Poison_Part: Stomach pain, salivation, sweating, nausea, vomiting. Skin irritation with tingling, redness, blisters, and cracks, either immed
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Stomach pain, salivation, sweating, nausea, vomiting. Skin irritation with tingling, redness, blisters, and cracks, either immediately or after a delay from contact, and may spread away from the point of contact; an allergic reaction.
id_plant_info.Severity: Causes only low toxicity if eaten. Skin irritation minor, or lasting only for a few minutes.

id_plant_info.Description: Perennial, erect herb with stinging hairs; leaves opposite, simple, coarsely toothed, narrowly heart-shaped; flowers small, greenish, in axillary clusters.
id_plant_info.Poison_Part: Stinging hairs on stems and leaves
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Intense burning and itching sensation lasting a few minutes
id_plant_info.Toxic_Principle: Mixture of chemicals, not well understood
id_plant_info.Severity: SKIN IRRITATION MINOR, OR LASTING ONLY FOR A FEW MINUTES

id_plant_info.Description: Climbing, woody vines or shrub; leaves alternate, pinnately divided with 7-19 leaflets each with a smooth margin; flowers large, pea-like, in elongated, terminal, pendent clusters, white or most often blue or violet; fruit a hairy, flattened pod with a few seeds.
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, stomach pain, diarrhea.
id_plant_info.Toxic_Principle: Wisterin, a glycoside, and a toxic resin.
id_plant_info.Severity: TOXIC ONLY IF LARGE QUANTITIES EATEN.

id_plant_info.Common_Name: Mountain laurel, ivy bush, mountain ivy
id_plant_info.Description: Large, evergreen shrub; leaves alternate and simple; flowers pinkish, in terminal clusters, each saucer-shaped with 5 shallow lobes, the 10 anthers at first stuck in small pockets; fruit a capsule; multiple cultivars available, including dwarf forms ('Minuet' grows to 3 ft.)
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Salivation, watering of eyes and nose, slow pulse, nausea, vomiting, sweating, abdominal pain, headache, tingling of skin, lack of coordination, convulsions, paralysis
id_plant_info.Toxic_Principle: Andromedotoxin, a resinoid; arbutin, a glycoside
id_plant_info.Severity: HIGHLY TOXIC, MAY BE FATAL IF EATEN!

id_plant_info.Description: Herbaceous, bulbous perennial; leaves long and strap-like; flowers small, in a spadix surrounded by a white spathe.
id_plant_info.Symptoms: Severe burning sensation and swelling of lips, tongue, and throat; stomach pain and diarrhea possible.
id_plant_info.Toxic_Principle: Calcium oxalate crystals and possibly others.
id_plant_info.Severity: HIGHLY TOXIC, MAY BE FATAL IF EATEN!
